explanations.b: It does not have multiple inputs.

questions.question: 4. Identify which statement is true for inverter?

answers.a: Any difference in inputs guarantees a high output
answers.b: Any difference in inputs guarantees a low output
answers.c: A high input gives a high output
answers.d: A low input gives a high output

explanations.a: Any difference in inputs guarantees a high output - The output of an inverter is determined by the specific input level, as explained. Simply having a difference in inputs does not guarantee a high output.
explanations.b: Any difference in inputs guarantees a low output - The output of an inverter is not guaranteed to be low for any difference in inputs. The specific input level determines the output.
explanations.c: In an inverter, a high input (typically represented as '1') results in a low output (typically represented as '0'), not a high output.
explanations.d: The inverter essentially inverts the input signal, so a low input results in a high output.

questions.question: 10. What is desirable β<sub>n</sub>/β<sub>p</sub> ratio for an inverter?

explanations.a: A βn/βp ratio of 0 would not be desirable for an inverter as it would result in an imbalanced operation between the n-device and the p-device.
explanations.b: In an ideal inverter, the βn/βp ratio is often chosen to be 1 to achieve symmetrical rise and fall times, as well as balanced performance for both high-to-low and low-to-high transitions.
explanations.c: A βn/βp ratio of 0.5 would not be desirable for an inverter as it would lead to asymmetrical behaviour and imbalanced performance between the n-device and the p-device.
explanations.d: A βn/βp ratio of ∞ (infinity) would not be desirable for an inverter as it would result in imbalanced operation between the n-device and the p-device and can lead to performance issues.
